Introduction

Otosclerosis results from an imbalance of bone resorption and deposition that leads to the stiffening and ultimate fixation of the stapes.  This dampens the transmission of sound energy from the tympanic membrane to the cochlea, resulting in progressive conductive hearing loss.

Pathogenesis

Otosclerosis is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by abnormal bone remodeling of the otic capsule, the dense portion of the temporal bone that encases the inner ear.  It most commonly affects the area around the oval window, where the stapes footplate interfaces with the vestibule of the inner ear (

).

In the early stages, osteoclastic bone resorption is followed by the deposition of spongiotic bone, which is eventually replaced by dense, sclerotic bone.  As the bone becomes sclerotic and less elastic, the stapes becomes fixed in place, reducing its ability to transmit sound vibrations into the cochlea (

figure 1
).  This results in progressive conductive hearing loss.  In rare cases, the disease process may extend to involve the cochlea, leading to sensorineural hearing loss.

Risk factors

  • Genetics:  Autosomal dominant inheritance with variable penetrance.
  • Female sex.
  • Age 20-40.
  • Hormonal factors:  Pregnancy and hormonal changes, which may accelerate progression.

Clinical presentation

  • Progressive conductive hearing loss (worsens over years).
  • Mixed conductive and sensorineural hearing loss, which may occur if the cochlea is affected, but this is less common.
  • Bilateral ear involvement:  Symptoms typically start in one ear and progress to involve both.
  • Tinnitus, which may worsen with disease progression.
  • Paracusis of Willis:  Paradoxic improvement of hearing in noisy environments; background noise is poorly transmitted through the impaired middle ear, whereas transmission of sound waves from raised voices via bone conduction (which generates stronger vibrations) is increased.
  • Normal otoscopy (although excessive bony resorption can expose underlying blood vessels, leading to a reddish hue behind the tympanic membrane).

Differential diagnosis

  • Cerumen impaction:  Can result in conductive hearing loss due to progressive obstruction of the external auditory canal by ear wax.  Canal occlusion is easily visible on otoscopy, and hearing loss is reversible with wax removal.
  • Chronic otitis media:  May result in conductive hearing loss, but it is typically accompanied by ear pain and/or fullness, and otoscopy would show retraction of the tympanic membrane or fluid in the middle ear.
  • Tympanic membrane perforation:  Typically occurs from a traumatic injury (eg, due to cotton swab insertion), barotrauma, or severe middle ear infection and presents with acute onset of conductive hearing loss, ear pain, and otorrhea.  Hearing typically resolves once the perforation heals (within weeks).

Diagnosis

Otosclerosis is typically diagnosed through a combination of clinical evaluation, audiologic testing, and imaging (when needed for confirmation).  Clinical factors that increase suspicion for otosclerosis include:

  • Gradual hearing loss in young adults, particularly women, without ear pain/trauma.
  • Positive family history of hearing loss at a young age.
  • Normal otoscopic examination.

Tuning fork testing can differentiate between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss and narrow the possible diagnoses (

):

  • Rinne test:  Compares air conduction to bone conduction.  Otosclerosis results in bone conduction > air conduction (abnormal), indicating conductive hearing loss.
  • Weber test:  Compares sound perception between ears.  Otosclerosis causes sound to lateralize to the affected ear.  Conductive hearing loss prevents the transmission of ambient noise, so bone-conducted sound is perceived more strongly in the ear with conductive hearing loss.

Audiometry confirms conductive hearing loss and may show a characteristic Carhart notch, especially around 2,000 Hz, which represents a dip in bone-conduction threshold due to stapes fixation.  Tympanometry of the tympanic membrane may demonstrate reduced mobility of the stapes.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging studies

There are no specific laboratory tests for otosclerosis, but high-resolution noncontrast CT imaging of the temporal bones is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis.  CT findings may include areas of spongiotic or sclerotic bone near the oval or round windows and a thickened stapes footplate.  Cochlea involvement may reveal radiolucent foci extending around the cochlea, creating a double ring or halo sign.

Management

Conservative treatment involves the use of hearing aids, which amplify sound.  They are effective for most patients with conductive hearing loss, and they are especially useful in nonsurgical candidates or patients who decline surgery.

Surgery is the treatment of choice and has a high success rate for restoring hearing.  Procedures include a stapedectomy (removes the stapes bone and replaces it with a prosthesis that transmits the sound vibrations) and stapedotomy (a small hole is made in the stapes footplate, and a prosthesis is inserted and connected to the incus to bypass the fixed stapes and transmit sound vibrations).

Prognosis

Most patients with otosclerosis have an excellent prognosis following surgery, with conductive hearing loss improving in approximately 90%-95% of cases.  However, patients with a significant sensorineural component (cochlear involvement) may experience only partial improvement because surgical correction addresses the conductive but not the sensorineural deficit.

Summary

Otosclerosis (

) is a condition that causes progressive hearing loss due to abnormal bone remodeling in the inner ear, leading to the fixation of the stapes footplate.  It most commonly presents in young adults, particularly women, with conductive hearing loss and a normal otoscopic examination.  Diagnosis is based on clinical history/examination, audiometry, and, in some cases, CT scan of the temporal bones.  Surgical intervention offers significant improvement in hearing for the majority of patients.
